bibl.title: Letter from A.J. Warren to Philip Showalter Hench, November 24, 1952

div1.p: Warren, of the Rockefeller Foundation, replies to Hench's inquiry about Reed's formula for the development of yellow fever. He states that Reed's fundamental conclusions are still accepted, but he does think it possible that some of Finlay's yellow fever cases may have been produced as a result of his experiments.

div1.head: Letter from A.J. Warren to Philip Showalter Hench, November 24, 1952
div1.opener:
THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
49 WEST 49th STREET, NEW YORK 20
November 24, 1952
DIVISION OF MEDICINE AND PUBLIC HEALTH
CABLE ADDRESS: ROCKFOUND, NEW YORK
AIR MAIL
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter of November 20 to Dr. Strode is hereby acknowl-
edged. Since Dr. Strode retired from the direction of the Inter-
national Health Division in May, 1951 I am replying to your com-
munication on his behalf.

My belief is that research work in recent years has not
revealed any information which would tend to weaken in any way the
fundamental conclusions of Walter Reed and his colleagues. In
general, virus appears to circulate in the blood of humans infected
with yellow fever for a period of about three days. In a few
instances small amounts of virus have been encountered on the fourth
day and I believe very occasionally on the fifth day. Probably
there is little likelihood of mosquitoes becoming infected by biting
a patient as late as the fifth day.

As far as the length of incubation in the mosquito is con-
cerned, it appears to be directly related to the temperature at
which the insect is maintained. If you will consult pages 240-241
of Dr. Strode's volume on yellow fever you will find a discussion
of this point. Under laboratory conditions incubation periods
may be as short as four days at 37°C. and be prolonged to eighteen
days at 21°C. Probably in nature eight to fourteen days would
cover most situations.

I have not studied the records of Dr. Finlay's experiments
with care but I should think it quite possible that some of the
cases of yellow fever which he is said to have produced in volunteers
may have been transmitted by the bite of his mosquitoes. The crux
of the matter as I see it is that these demonstrations were not
conclusive.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, A. J. Warren, M.D.
Director Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
